content: I have updated the tests and validators. :/

To be more feasible for guessing the rules in reverse mode, I think there should be some sets of tests that have the same digit sum. Right now the only clue one might get is noticing all numbers are squares, but that doesn't seem enough to me.

Well, if enough other people comment that this is simple enough with the current tests, it might be just my problem then.

Aside from Niako's note, I think the statement makes zero sense.
edit: do we not care about statements for reverse mode? maybe add a new category "reverse mode ultrahard version" - even by finding the puzzle in the contribution list you still can not understand these.
I get that it's only reverse mode, but the statement/title does not make sense. "Sum squared" would probably be more on the nose.
Validators should not be the same as the tests!
Still this gets validated within 10 minutes, unbelievable XD ...
Yeah I know. Noticed this one second after sending it
Well, it's a reverse only CoC XD.
Blame me if this question is stupid, but what should the validators look like in this case?
Was just thinking the same thing... no CoC puzzle should ever be allowed if the validators are the same as the test cases.

The tests are visible, there is no challenge if the tests are the same as the validators as you can hardcode the solution. Validators have to be different (but of similar size as the associated tests).

@eaarslew: Yes indeed, this should ideally be automatically tested when submitting a puzzle (as the solution is tested against every testcase).
Thx, didn't rly know what they exactly mean, was the first Clash I commited
For example, with the test case using input "21" the corresponding validator could use input "12". Same complexity, but prevents hardcoding.
@Schokoriegler Please edit and fix the validators (it should go without saying)!

Please update the test cases.

Doc is here: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/defining-test-cases
BTW right now I see the Edit button on Classic puzzles but not on CoC!?

I need to make this clearer but this is why: 

https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/moderation
Oh, 300 clashes needed, fair enough. Honestly approver rights threshold could also be upped for CoC (lots of clashes are approved very quickly without being seriously reviewed).
Believe me, reaching 300 CoC was a real pain. :(

yeah, I realize 50 is perhaps too low. Could be 150?

Another issue is that creators are unable to know if puzzles/coc already exist since you can see the all list of accepted contribs only with editor rights. Maybe it's not much of an issue, but as a new creator, I could feel bad if the contrib I just took time to create is fine but already exists, hence refused.

I think that 50 and 150 are almost the same.
Recently, I have spend two evening on CoCs, and the vast majority of my opponents were lvl 4 or less, with far more experience in clash than myself.


A better solution would be to restore the requirement on the level (aka, people who have solved easy+medium puzzles are allowed to contribute).

Another solution would be to unlock contribution as soon as one reach a score of more than 25pts (for instance) in the CoC leaderboard.

As for the list of already-approved CoCs, this is a ***MAJOR*** issue.

New contributors, that usually have no way to know if a contribution already exists, expose themselves to both a waste of time and unpleasant remarks along with the refusal.


One way to fix this would be to have a single *public* page that lists all the approved CoC, with the following:
- title of the CoC
- name of the contributor
- name of the 2/3 acceptors
- list of the available modes
- list of tags (ideally, a one-line summary... but we don't have this).

Statistics on each CoC (number of time it was proposed, average success per mode, etc.) would also be useful to identify potential issues.

@Stilgart Considering the fact that reviewing the CoC is also a real pain xD , I certainly won't try to reach 300 clashes just for that ;-) .

More seriously, I agree with everything Stilgart said. The CoC statistics could also include general statistics on the feedback (I don't know if people actually give much feedback, but they are invited to after each clash).

There is also a problem with the fact that once a puzzle is accepted, the author sometimes considers that it's all good and does not answer anymore in the comments or implements required modifications.
This leads to that (serious contradiction between statement & testcases that is a pain to fix + fixes that get reverted to something wrong...) :
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1912ed718fdb06816b8c76c2bbc2346b4a70 & https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/community-puzzle-the-frog-jump-1/
or that (bad IO):
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/809595dc68b46a6e61f8f2c0ded351d22e6
or that kind of stuff with inadequate statement ("because I plan to have a second version"):
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1990790766371c406da1e4b7d4e33ab5e88f
